NATIONAL NEWS






Valley power play over coal continues



Jun. 6--WASILLA -- Hit the switch and the lights go on. That simple act is such a habit that few think about where their power comes from.  Until someone suggests plunking down a coal-burning plant in their neighborhood, near their cabin or their favorite fishing hole. Then it's the talk of the town. "The basic issue is nobody wants a coal plant in their backyard," said Jim Sykes of Lazy ...


Jun 6, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Emissions limits could be costly



Jun. 6--The amount of carbon dioxide that is emitted into the atmosphere by the Lawrence Energy Center has raised environmental concerns.  Among those worried are Lawrence residents Ray Dean and his wife, Sarah, who filed a lawsuit last week against the Kansas Department of Health and Environment, which monitors air quality. The lawsuit, filed in Shawnee County District Court, contends KDHE is ...


Jun 6, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Bill could slow Diablo relicensing: If passed, the bill would put the power plant's relicensing on hold until the Energy Commission completes a nuclear study



Jun. 6--The Assembly's Appropriations Committee has approved a bill that would put the relicensing of Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant on hold until a study on the future of nuclear power in California is completed.  The bill by Assemblyman Mark Leno, D-San Francisco, would forbid the state Public Utilities Commission from approving any further use of electricity ratepayer money for costs ...


Jun 6, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Public Utility Commission officer says electric competition is here to stay



Jun. 6--James H. Cawley told state senators Tuesday that Pennsylvania must find a way to make electric competition work because returning to the old system is impossible.  Cawley, vice chairman of the state Public Utility Commission, was one of several witnesses at a joint hearing held by two Senate committees on Gov. Ed Rendell's energy independence package.


Jun 6, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



McClendon says he's behind Duke ads



Jun. 6--Aubrey McClendon, co-founder, chairman and CEO of Chesapeake Energy Corporation, said Tuesday that he is the anonymous Oklahoma City oilman who purchased several full-page newspaper advertisements along the East Coast praising the Duke men's lacrosse team.  McClendon, a 1981 Duke graduate, said he got the idea from a fellow alumnus who purchased a full-page ad in USA Today immediately ...


Jun 6, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



DWP feeling the heat of understaffing, aging equipment



Jun. 5--Nearly a year after a heat wave triggered mass power outages across Los Angeles and exposed problems in the city's aging electrical system, the DWP has replaced thousands of transformers, repaired hundreds of problem circuits and hired private crews on standby.  But as Los Angeles prepares for another potentially record-breaking summer, some are questioning whether the repairs will be ...


Jun 5, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Wind moving to forefront



Jun. 6--Wind is moving from being a niche market to the mainstream.  "This is really a pretty big change. ... There are 42 utilities at this conference," said Pat Wood, chairman of the North American advisory board for wind developer Airtricity. Wood was at the WindPower 2007 conference in Los Angeles on Tuesday, along with other speakers who addressed the challenges for wind power arising from ...

Dirty business of coal could get makeover: State has high hopes for cleaner technology



Jun. 6--State regulators on Tuesday signed off on plans to build one of the nation's first plants that would turn dirty coal into cleaner fuel, generating electricity while dramatically reducing smog and mercury pollution.  If built amid cornfields outside Taylorville, about 200 miles southwest of Chicago, the 630-megawatt plant would provide a lucrative boost to the state's beleaguered coal ...


Jun 6, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Rell Signs Energy Bill; Vetoes 2 Items



Jun. 5--Gov. M. Jodi Rell signed a comprehensive energy bill Monday, but she pledged to work with lawmakers over the next two days to restore two provisions that she rejected with a line-item veto.  The provisions she vetoed were an additional $2.5 million to expand Operation Fuel, a program that helps poorer residents pay their fuel bills, and programs promoting energy conservation and renewable ...


Jun 5, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Tax On Power Plants Rejected



Jun. 6--A windfall profits tax on state power plants that would have returned as much as $350 million to property owners struggling to pay their electric bills failed in the House of Representatives Tuesday.  The House rejected the proposal 95-49. Opponents were not convinced that the tax would lead to savings for consumers and said the proposal did not resolve the underlying problem of ...


Jun 6, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



TXU is fined $5 million



Jun. 6--TXU CORP. -- already under scrutiny for alleged price gouging -- is in hot water again.  The Dallas-based energy giant has agreed to pay the Texas Public Utility Commission a $5 million fine to resolve allegations that it broke state law by signing up thousands of businesses to new one-year electric contracts without obtaining their explicit consent, according to a 10-page settlement ...


Jun 6, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Power plants spared tax



Jun. 6--WINDFALL PROFITS LEFT UNTOUCHED  HARTFORD -- State House lawmakers rejected a proposal Tuesday to place a windfall profits tax on some Connecticut power plants to pay for more than $400 million a year in rebates to state electricity consumers. The amendment failed on a bipartisan 49-95 House vote after opponents warned an untested windfall profits tax could backfire and produce even ...


Jun 6, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Brookhaven again OKs power plant



Jun. 6--The Brookhaven Town Council yesterday voted once again to approve an environmental review and building permits for the proposed Caithness Long Island power plant in Yaphank, but opponents said they expect to be back in court as early as next week to raise objections.  By a 5-to-1 vote, the board, acting after a judge recently nullified its July 2006 approval as "arbitrary and capricious," ...


Jun 6, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Judge to consider lawyers' withdrawal: Attorneys want out of the case of former Westar executive because of lack of payment from utility.



Jun. 6--TOPEKA -- A federal judge is expected to decide in a few days whether to allow defense lawyers for former Westar Energy executive Spielas Lake to withdraw from his criminal case.  U.S. District Judge Julie Robinson took the request under advisement Tuesday after the lawyers complained that trying the case a third time, with no assurance of payment, posed a hardship to them and their law ...


Jun 6, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Tenaska project faces hurdles



Jun. 6--Omaha-based power company Tenaska Inc. received an air quality permit in Illinois Tuesday to build what experts say would be the cleanest full-sized, coal-powered electricity plant on the planet.  But the project faces hurdles that could delay construction and would need additional work to take advantage of all of its anti-pollution possibilities, such as capturing its carbon dioxide.


Jun 6, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News



Proposed PJM power line might skirt Port Jervis



Jun. 6--PORT JERVIS -- A proposed 500-kilovolt power line could run near Port Jervis and parts of Pike County, Pa.  The $350 million line is being proposed by PJM Interconnection, an independent regional transmission organization, which manages electric transmission services of the Mid-Atlantic power grid in 13 states and Washington, D.C. The power line would run from a nuclear power plant in ...


Jun 6, 2007 Knight Ridder Tribune Business News





GE increases its renewable portfolio



Tuesday's purchase of a Canadian hydroelectric plant and investments in two wind farms will boost GE's stake in renewables. GE will acquire, for $180 million, two 50 percent stakes in Sweetwater and Roscoe wind farms in Texas. The two farms combined have an output of 450 megawatts, boosting GE's wind power portfolio to 1,900 megawatts. ...

Campaign aims to lower power use in peak times



With the hot summer months looming, Utah consumers again will be asked to conserve on their electricity use when the state's power grid is under its most stress. For the seventh year in a row, Utahns will be able to find out when that critical point is about to be reached courtesy of the 'PowerForward' campaign, an early warning system sponsored by the state's Department of Environmental Quality ...

'Remarkable and historic': Energy magnate's wife to get $184M in divorce



CHICAGO -- An energy magnate's estranged wife was awarded $184 million Monday in what appears to be one of the biggest divorce verdicts in U.S. history. Citing irreconcilible differences, Maya Polsky, a 55-year-old homemaker and art gallery owner, filed for divorce from her husband, Michael Polsky, in 2003. Judge William Boyd had ruled in October that Maya Polsky was entitled to half of the ...

Senate gives initial OK to greenhouse gas bill



AUGUSTA - The Senate voted unanimously today to gave initial approval to a measure that allows Maine to join a multi-state effort to reduce greenhouse gas pollution. The 10 northern states in the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative agree to freeze power plant emissions from 2009 to 2015 and cut them 10 percent by 2019. In Maine, the state's six largest power plants would pay for the right to ...

(AP) - NorthWestern Energy announced plans Tuesday for a transmission line running from Montana to Idaho which it said could carry energy from developing wind power plants to power-hungry markets. Turkey-manure power plant raises stink with environmentalists



BENSON, Minnesota: For anyone curious about what thousands of tons of turkey manure looks like, piled high in an olfactory-assaulting mountain, this old railroad stop on the extreme edge of alternative energy production is the place to be. Thanks to the abundance of local droppings, Benson is home to a new $200 million power plant that burns turkey waste to produce electricity.
